column1: George Bartenstein Lauren Bergsten, Sarah Blake and Denise Burton
David Joseph Carpenter was born to Elwood and Frances Carpenter in San
David has a pronounced stutter.  Is teased in school due to stutter and dress.  He
05/33-adulthood 3-18 was also made to take ballet and violin lessons.  He was dressed in a fancy
manner.  Beaten repeatedly and severely by his mother.
1944 14 Committed to Napa State Hospital for sex offenses.
Molested his two cousins, ages 8 and 3; Sentenced to California Youth
11/05/55 25 Married Ellen Heattle, she was 19 years old.
Third child, Circe Anne, born.  Wife reports that Carpenter had enormous
sexual appetite, had to have intercourse three times nightly.
Attacked Lois DeAndrade.  Brought clothesline, knife, and claw hammer.
Stabbed her hand, hit her in head with hammer at least six times.  Military
Police Officer Wayne Hicks hears DeAndrade and arrives on scene.  Carpenter
07/60 30 attempts to shoot Hicks but misses.  Hicks returns fire, hitting Carpenter two
times, once in abdomen and once in leg.  Carpenter is charged with 1 count of
assault with intent to commit murder and 2 counts of assault with a deadly
Sentenced to 5 years on 2 counts and 4 years on 1 count for a total of 14 years
in U.S. Federal Court.  Offenses were committed on federal property.  During
stay in prison, psychiatrist reports Carpenter has “sociopathic personality

column3: Final divorce from Ellen decreed.
Paroled from prison.
Married Helen.

Attacked Cheryl Lynn Smith.  He stabbed her, ripped her clothes off, but shemanaged to get away.  She got his license plate number.  The same dayCarpenter broke into a home, kidnapped, and raped Wilma Joyce (no last nameto protect identity).  He then stole her car.
Held Sharon O’Donnell with shotgun.  She escaped while he was changinglicense plates.
Stole a car from Lucille Davis.
Kidnapped and raped Barbara (no last name used to protect her identity).  Herinfant was present during attack and she remarked that Carpenter was kind toher child.  He was arrested the same day.
Escaped from jail by cutting through bars and going out the skylight.Recaptured a short time later.

Convicted of armed robbery and sentenced to 5 years to life; convicted ofkidnapping and sentenced to 1 year to 25 years; convicted of auto theft andescape and sentenced to six months to 5 years on each.
Convicted of kidnapping and robbery through a plea bargain in Santa Cruz.
Paroled to a federal halfway house.
Murdered Edda Kane.  She was shot and left naked in Mt. Tamalpais State Park.
Released from halfway house and moves in with elderly parents.
Began working for key chain distributor.
Murdered Barbara Swartz.  She was stabbed repeatedly and found in Mt.Tamalpais State Park.
Rick Stowers and Cindy Moreland disappear.
Anne Alderson found dead.  She had been raped, shot 3 times and redressed.Near Mt. Tamalpais State Park.

Murdered Diane O’Connell and Shauna May.  Raped, strangled, and shotO’Connell.  Possible sexual assault on May and shot her, in Point Reyes Park.Found in shallow graves.  Rick Stowers and Cindy Moreland found dead, alsoin Point Reyes Park.
Anna Kelly Menjivar disappears.
Candace Dawn Townsend moves in with Carpenter and his parents.
Begins working for Econo Quick Print.

Murdered Ellen Hansen.  Shot her three times.  Shot her companion, StevenHaertle.  He survived to give an accurate description of killer.  Along with this,other hikers had noticed a red, foreign car around the time of the murders.  Theywere in Henry Cowell Redwood State Park.
Candace Townsend moves out.
Heather Scaggs disappears.
Carpenter is arrested.

Heather Scaggs’ body is found.  Had been covered with brush in a shallowgrave.  Appeared to have been raped.  Shot and found in Big Basin RedwoodState Park.  She was a co-worker of Carpenter’s.  Police go to question him athis house and notice his red Fiat car in the driveway and that he matches thepolice sketch of the suspected “trailside killer.”  Police run background checkand find past felony arrests.  Then they show Stephen Haertle a mug shot of himand he fingers Carpenter as the killer.
Kelly Menjivar’s remains are found in Castle Rock State Park.
Charged with 5 counts of murder, rape, and attempted rape in Santa CruzCounty.  Change of venue granted due to pretrial publicity - moved to LosAngeles.
Two juried impaneled at once, one to determine guilt and one for sentencing, atotal of 33 people - jurors and alternates.  Took 83 days to complete voir dire
questioning.
Found guilty of all charges.
Sentenced to death.
Charged with 5 counts of murder, 2 counts of rape, and 1 count of attemptedrape in Marin County.
Change of venue granted.  Moved to San Diego.
Convicted of 5 counts of murder, rape, and attempted rape in Marin Countycases.
Carpenter sentenced to death a second time for Marin County cases.
Mistrial declared because a juror had found out Carpenter was convicted ofmurder and sentenced to death in Santa Cruz County cases.  Later retried andfound guilty of all Marin County charges.
California Supreme Court upheld the death penalty for Carpenter.
California Supreme Court upheld the death penalty for Carpenter for the secondtime.  To date, he is still incarcerated in San Quentin Prison.

No, balding, crooked and yellow teeth, white and hairless hands
Yes, beaten by mother, went to school with bruises on legs, black eyes,visible welts
Yes, by both mother and father, told he was worthless.
Pulled down girl’s underpants at age 8.
Yes, described as a heavy drinker.
10th, but complete GED at McNeil Island.

Employed at key chain distributor and print shop
No, children’s mother did not allow visitation.  He saw his childrensporadically as adults.
Yes, only confirmed by one source.
Yes, during both incarcerations was examined by psychologist (priorto serial killings).
Yes, at age 14, Napa State Hospital
Assault and Battery with a hammer on a woman in 1961, two counts ofkidnapping and robbery in 1970.
Yes.  Escaped with four other inmates after being sentenced forkidnapping and robbery, but before being sent to prison.
Hikers and joggers in woodlands around San Francisco and SantaCruz.

column1: Left at scene, no attempt to hide
column2: Yes.  Six victims were simply left where they fell dead.
Yes.  Four victims were found in shallow graves not far from where hekilled them.
Death by the gas chamber at San Quentin.
